snippet: For Iraqi Sunnis, the struggle to retake Falluja from the Islamic State underscores the personal nature of war: a conflict of sons and brothers, nephews and neighbors.
abstract: Iraq's war has created bitter divide within country's Sunni population; look at battle to retake Falluja, Iraq, reveals that many of those fighting for Iraqi forces also have sons, brothers and nephews in same family fighting for Islamic State; rising tension within sect is triggering concern that Sunnis will not be able to reconcile even after war ends.

byline.original: By TIM ARANGO and FALIH HASSAN
byline.contributor: Omar Al-Jawoshy contributed reporting from Falluja and Baghdad, and employees of The New York Times from Diyala, Salahuddin and Anbar Provinces and Erbil, Iraq.

lead_paragraph: For Iraqi Sunnis, the struggle to retake Falluja from the Islamic State underscores the personal nature of war: a conflict of sons and brothers, nephews and neighbors.

headline.main: A War of Brothers in Iraq: ‘I Will Kill Him With My Own Hands’
headline.print_headline: Iraqi Brother but ISIS Enemy:  War Fractures Families and Sect

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
